constellations_other.name: Short films that sell: the power of TV advertising
constellations_other.description: The MTA’s "Dumb Ways to Die" has over 300 million views on YouTube with the campaign’s song known globally, having charted on iTunes in 28 countries. While light-hearted, at its core the hugely successful commercial carries a serious message: Be Safe Around Trains.

results.title: Flight Patterns

constellations_other.name: Future visions
constellations_other.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

results.description:
Flight Patterns was originally developed as a series of experiments for the project “Celestial Mechanics” by colleagues Scott Hessels and Gabriel Dunne at UCLA. FAA data was parsed and plotted using the Processing programming environment. The frames were composited with Adobe After Effects and/or Maya. - Aaron Koblin

results.title: Apple and Google stores suspend Parler app

constellations_other.name: Fake news: too little too late
constellations_other.description: Unbound Creations’ Headliner: NoviNews explores the impact of the media and fake news on society, something that is fast becoming one of the biggest concerns of our age.

results.title_for_label: Apple and Google stores suspend Parler app
results.description: After Trump was banned permanently from Twitter and Facebook in early 2021, many supporters of the alt-right movement (including controversial group The Proud Boys) began to use an alternative app called Parler. Google and Apple removed the app from their stores for inciting violence.
description_for_label: After Trump was banned permanently from Twitter and Facebook in early 2021, many supporters of the alt-right movement (including controversial group The Proud Boys) began to use an alternative app called Parler. Google and Apple removed the app from their stores for inciting violence.

results.title: Servant or Slave

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description: Servant or Slave follows the lives of five Aboriginal women who were stolen from their families and trained to be domestic servants. With the government exercising complete control over their wages, many thousands of Aboriginal girls and boys were effectively condemned to a treadmill of abuse, from which there was little hope of escape.
description_for_label: Servant or Slave follows the lives of five Aboriginal women who were stolen from their families and trained to be domestic servants. With the government exercising complete control over their wages, many thousands of Aboriginal girls and boys were effectively condemned to a treadmill of abuse, from which there was little hope of escape.

results.title: After the Apology

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description: Suellyn thought FACS would only remove children in extreme cases until her own grandchildren were taken. Hazel decided to take on the FACS system after her fourth grandchild was taken into state care. Jen Swan was raising her grandchildren until she was deemed unsuitable by FACS. The rate of Indigenous child removal has increased at an exponential rate since Prime Minister Kevin Rudd delivered the apology to the ‘stolen generations’ in 2008. Hazel started GMAR as a response to the rising rates of child removal and along the way she has been joined by families across Australia in the battle to bring the kids home. Together are not only taking on the system, they are changing it.
description_for_label: Suellyn thought FACS would only remove children in extreme cases until her own grandchildren were taken. Hazel decided to take on the FACS system after her fourth grandchild was taken into state care. Jen Swan was raising her grandchildren until she was deemed unsuitable by FACS. Hazel started GMAR as a response to the rising rates of child removal and along the way she has been joined by families across Australia in the battle to bring the kids home. Together are not only taking on the system, they are changing it.

results.title: VIDEO WORKS
results.brief_description: VIDEO WORKS is an immersive composite of three major video installations by Sydney-based Kudjala/Gangalu artist Daniel Boyd that map the gallery walls with Boyd’s infinite cosmos of dynamic compositions and prismatic colour.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description:
VIDEO WORKS is an immersive composite of three major video installations by Sydney-based Kudjala/Gangalu artist Daniel Boyd. A Darker Shade of Dark #1-4 (2012); History is Made at Night (2013); and Yamani (2018) will map the walls of the gallery with Boyd’s infinite cosmos of dynamic compositions and prismatic colour.

Set to a score by Canyons, VIDEO WORKS is an experience that is both otherworldly and grounded; expansive and atomic.
description_for_label:
VIDEO WORKS is an immersive composite of three major video installations by Sydney-based Kudjala/Gangalu artist Daniel Boyd. A Darker Shade of Dark #1-4 (2012); History is Made at Night (2013); and Yamani (2018) will map the walls of the gallery with Boyd’s infinite cosmos of dynamic compositions and prismatic colour.

Set to a score by Canyons, VIDEO WORKS is an experience that is both otherworldly and grounded; expansive and atomic.

results.title: Collisions: Lynette Wallworth
results.brief_description: A stunning VR experience, acclaimed filmmaker and artist Lynette Wallworth’s Collisions invites audiences on a journey to the land of Indigenous elder, Nyarri Nyarri Morgan and the Martu tribe in the remote Western Australian desert.

constellations_other.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_other.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

results.description:
A stunning VR experience, acclaimed filmmaker and artist Lynette Wallworth’s Collisions invites audiences on a journey to the land of indigenous elder, Nyarri Nyarri Morgan and the Martu tribe in the remote Western Australian desert.

When Nyarri Nyarri Morgan witnessed nuclear bomb testing in the Maralinga, he came into contact with western culture for the first time. It was a complete collision between technology and one of the oldest cultures in the world. The possibilities of virtual reality inspired artist Lynette Wallworth so much that, upon meeting Nyarri, she knew that it would be the perfect kind of immersive technology to share his story.
description_for_label:
A stunning VR experience, acclaimed filmmaker and artist Lynette Wallworth’s Collisions invites audiences on a journey to the land of indigenous elder, Nyarri Nyarri Morgan and the Martu tribe in the remote Western Australian desert.

When Nyarri Nyarri Morgan witnessed nuclear bomb testing in the Maralinga, he came into contact with western culture for the first time. It was a complete collision between technology and one of the oldest cultures in the world. The possibilities of virtual reality inspired artist Lynette Wallworth so much that, upon meeting Nyarri, she knew that it would be the perfect kind of immersive technology to share his story.

results.brief_description: Julie Gough’s The Promise (2011) uses light and shadow to illuminate the mistreatment of First Peoples.

results.title: Out of the Sea Like a Cloud

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.title_for_label: Out of the Sea Like a Cloud
results.description: A Badtjala woman from Fraser Island, Queensland, Fiona Foley’s film looks at the oldest recorded encounter in song, by the Badtjala, of the 1770 Endeavour ships voyage when it and its crew sailed past Takky Wooroo, K’gari (Indian Head, Fraser Island). Activating a space not embarked on previously, and one little known to the Australian nation, Foley brings Indigenous Knowledge’s to the fore of the film by profiling the surviving English component of the Badtjala song which details the ships voyage and its observation of European men handed down over generations of Badtjala oral history. The film also pulls on another thread of Queensland history, the legal use of opium in the state of Queensland prior to the introduction of the 1897 legislation, The Aboriginals Protection and Restriction of the Sale of Opium Act.
description_for_label: A Badtjala woman from Fraser Island, Queensland, Fiona Foley’s film looks at the oldest recorded encounter in song, by the Badtjala, of the 1770 Endeavour ships voyage when it and its crew sailed past Takky Wooroo, K’gari (Indian Head, Fraser Island). Activating a space not embarked on previously, and one little known to the Australian nation, Foley brings Indigenous Knowledge’s to the fore of the film by profiling the surviving English component of the Badtjala song which details the ships voyage and its observation of European men handed down over generations of Badtjala oral history. The film also pulls on another thread of Queensland history, the legal use of opium in the state of Queensland prior to the introduction of the 1897 legislation, The Aboriginals Protection and Restriction of the Sale of Opium Act.

results.title: Looky Looky Here Comes Cooky

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description: A songline for 21st century Australia – a fresh look at the Cook legend from a First Nations’ perspective – the songline tells of connection to country, resistance and survival and features the cheeky, acerbic and heartfelt showman – Steven Oliver and a host of outstanding Indigenous singer/songwriters.
description_for_label: A songline for 21st century Australia – a fresh look at the Cook legend from a First Nations’ perspective – the songline tells of connection to country, resistance and survival and features the cheeky, acerbic and heartfelt showman – Steven Oliver and a host of outstanding Indigenous singer/songwriters.
